Graphical abstract Overcoming the technical limitation of each component in water electrolyzer such as catalyst, membrane, and bipolar plate can cut down the H2 production cost, which can be initiated by understanding their respective technical targets. Continuous efforts are underway to reduce carbon emissions worldwide in response to global climate change. Water electrolysis technology, in conjunction with renewable energy, is considered the most feasible hydrogen production technology based on the viable possibility of large-scale hydrogen production and the zero-carbon-emission nature of the process. However, for hydrogen produced via water electrolysis systems to be utilized in various fields in practice, the unit cost of hydrogen production must be reduced to $1/kgH2. To achieve this unit cost, technical targets for water electrolysis have been suggested regarding components in the system. In this paper, the types of water electrolysis systems and the limitations of water electrolysis system components are explained. We suggest guideline with recent trend for achieving this technical target and insights for the potential utilization of water electrolysis technology. Keywords Water electrolysis Hydrogen production Technical target Electrochemistry 1 Introduction As per the Paris Agreement—adopted in 2015 as a global response to climate change—195 countries have pledged to limit the level of mean temperature increase at ≤1.5 °C [1]. A five-year nationally determined contribution (NDC) has been suggested for each country to achieve this target, and the ultimate goal is for various countries including the E.U., U.S., and Japan, to become carbon-neutral by 2050. South Korea also aims to reduce its carbon emissions to 40% of their 2018 level by 2030 and ultimately reach carbon neutrality by 2050 [2]. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), global investment in clean energy and movement away from fossil fuels has continued since 2015, with a notable increase in clean energy investment since 2020. “Clean energy” refers to new renewable energy technologies, nuclear power generation, grids, storage, and low-carbon-emission fuels. Furthermore, many companies are known to be investing or planning to invest in new renewable energy technologies, carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS), direct air capture systems (DACS), and hydrogen technology (Fig. 1b) [2]. In particular, using hydrogen as an energy carrier is considered the ultimate solution for achieving a carbon-neutral society, as it can be produced from water indefinitely and does not generate greenhouse gases upon combustion [3]. Hence, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) has recently announced that “Clean Hydrogen” is key to achieving a net-zero economy by 2050, in which decarbonization based on hydrogen technology is realized across all sectors of society from industry to transport (Fig. 2 ) [4]. While the use of hydrogen itself is important to achieve a sustainable decarbonized society, the production method and source of the hydrogen are equally important. Consequently, hydrogen has recently been classified into four categories: black hydrogen, grey hydrogen, blue hydrogen, and green hydrogen (Fig. 3 ). Black hydrogen is a by-product of fossil fuel reforming, which generates the largest quantity of CO2 (20 kgCO 2/kgH2) among the hydrogen production processes. Grey hydrogen is a by-product in natural gas reforming and pyrolysis, resulting in carbon emissions of approximately 9 kgCO2/kgH2. Blue hydrogen, like grey hydrogen, is a product of natural gas reforming. However, in the case of blue hydrogen, additional carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology is employed, with the released CO2 captured or stored to reduce CO2 production in the hydrogen production process. The generation of green hydrogen via water electrolysis using electricity based on renewable energywithout any associated CO2 production represents the ultimate goal. Currently, grey hydrogen exhibits the lowest unit cost (approximately $1.5/kgH2); thus, the most commercially available hydrogen is grey hydrogen. Efforts have been made to lower the unit costs of green hydrogen and blue hydrogen to $1/kgH2 to lower the dependence on grey hydrogen and reduce CO2 emissions. However, the hydrogen obtained through water electrolysis currently cannot be classified as truly green hydrogen because the water electrolysis process is powered by conventional electricity sources. The unit cost of hydrogen production via water electrolysis is significantly dependent on the unit cost of electricity generation; moreover, infrastructure to connect water electrolysis systems to renewable energy sources remains lacking. Thus, the hydrogen obtained from water electrolysis is classified as pink hydrogen (nuclear-power-based hydrogen production) or yellow hydrogen (grid-based hydrogen production) [5]. Hence, to ensure that the majority of hydrogen produced is green hydrogen, it is necessary to use electric power technology based on renewable energy. Additionally, the unit cost of hydrogen should be reduced by addressing the inherent limitations of water electrolysis systems. In this paper, different types of water electrolysis systems are introduced, with the technical and cost-related limitations of each component of the water electrolysis system summarized to offer insights into future research directions and potential applications of water electrolysis systems. 2 Water electrolysis system During water electrolysis, water molecules are directly decomposed into gaseous H2 and O2 through hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) upon applying a voltage to a cell comprising electrodes and water as the electrolyte. 2.1 Types of water electrolysis systems Acidic media (1) Anode: 2H2O (l) → O2 (g) + 4H+ (aq) + 4e− (2) Cathode: 2H+ (aq) + 2e− → H2 (g) Alkaline media (3) Anode: 4OH− (aq) → 2H2O (l) + O2 (g) + 4e− (4) Cathode: 2H2O (l) + 2e− → H2 (g) + 2OH− (aq) High temperature (5) Anode: O2−→ O2 + 4e− (6) Cathode: 2H2O + 4e−→ 2H2 + O2− Water electrolysis systems are classified according to their operation temperature as low-temperature (room temperature to 100 °C) and high-temperature (<400 °C: proton-conducting ceramics; 800–1000 °C: solid oxide water electrolyzers (SOWEs)) systems. The low-temperature systems are further classified according to the type of electrolyte as alkaline water electrolyzers (AWEs), proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWEs), and anion exchange membrane water electrolyzers (AEMWEs) [6]. As the reaction equations vary based on the operating conditions (temperature and electrolyte), the suitable cell structure and components consequently are different as summarized in Fig. 4 and Table 1 . To briefly explain each water electrolyzer type, the AWE represents the first-generation water electrolysis system (Fig. 4a) and the most traditional one. The performance of the electrochemical reaction (current density vs. overpotential) is significantly influenced by the electrochemical catalytic activity and electrolyte resistance. To decrease the electrolyte resistance, a high-concentration alkaline solution (20–30 wt% KOH) is used as the electrolyte. As the distance between the two electrodes decreases, the resistance of the electrolyte falls, while the probability of explosion due to the crossover of the produced hydrogen and oxygen gas increases. To ensure proper gas isolation and high OH− ion conductivity, a porous ZrO2-stabilized polyphenylenesulfide (PPS) mesh (e.g., Zirfon®) that allows the movement of KOH electrolyte is being used as a separator. However, there is still a possibility of gas crossover through porous membranes, and this issue becomes more pronounced at high pressures, making it challenging to directly provide high-pressure hydrogen. To address these limitations, advanced electrolysis technologies use gas-impermeable ion exchange membranes that selectively transport only the ions (H+ or OH−) participating in the reaction to the opposite electrode. This is implemented in both PEMWE and AEMWE. In the PEMWE, a perfluorosulfonic acid (PFSA) ion exchange membrane (e.g., Nafion®) that selectively allows the migration of cations such as H+ is located directly between the two electrodes, allowing the construction of a zero-gap cell without crossover (Fig. 4b) [8]. Typically, the PFSA ion exchange membrane has a thickness of 50–175 μm. Although ion conductivity could be increased by further reducing the membrane thickness, a thinner ion exchange membrane would not be durable due to its high gas permeability and low mechanical strength [9,10], in addition to its vulnerability to the heat generated at high current densities. Additionally, the H+ causes the local pH to become near-acidic at the interface between the ion exchange membrane and the electrode, which imposes limitations on the selection of electrocatalyst and other component materials. Precious metals such as Pt and Ir are typically used as catalysts as they are the only metals that can remain in metal or metal-oxide form in such an environment [11]. Because of the gas-impermeable PFSA membrane, operation at the high current density is possible, which is attributed to the fast supply of proton due to ensuring adequate ion conductivity without using high-concentration KOH as the electrolyte; hence, deionized (DI) water can be directly supplied to the water electrolysis system. To overcome the constraints in selecting catalyst materials for PEMWE, the next-generation electrolysis system known as AEMWE has gained attention by shifting the local pH at the interface between the electrode and the ion exchange membrane to an alkaline state (Fig. 4c). AEMWE employs anion exchange membranes from the divinylbenzene (DVB) series that selectively transport OH− ions, allowing the use of cost-effective non-precious metal catalysts like Ni, Co, or Fe as the primary catalyst material. However, the catalytic activity in the alkaline environment for the HER is lower compared to the acidic environment, primarily due to the fact that the rate of water dissociation in alkaline conditions is approximately 2–3 times slower. Thus, to achieve high HER activity in alkaline conditions, it is essential for the catalysts to possess characteristics that facilitate the binding of hydrogen species and the dissociation of water [12]. Furthermore, due to the inherently lower ion conductivity of OH− ions compared to H+ ions and the relatively lower technological maturity of anion exchange membranes, in some cases, the use of KOH as the feedwater is necessary to ensure sufficient conductivity when operating AEMWE, rather than relying solely on DI water as feedwater. The performance of AEM can be improved through enhancing the stability of the cationic group, employing an ether-free backbone, and utilizing chemical crosslinking approaches [13]. Lastly, the SOWE, which utilizes high-temperature water vapor instead of liquid water, stands apart from the three other electrolysis system by using ceramic-based materials due to the high-temperature operating conditions (Fig. 4d). Since the ions transported between the two electrodes are the oxygen anion (O2−), yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) is employed as the ion separator to ensure efficient ion conduction. While SOWE may not operate at pressures higher than atmospheric pressure, it offers the advantage of potentially reducing the required voltage for electrolysis below 1.23 V (ΔG = ΔH – Q, ΔG = electrical energy input, ΔH = total energy input) due to the heat energy (Q = TΔS) provided by the high operating temperature as shown in Fig. 4(e). 2.2 Components of water electrolysis systems Water electrolysis systems require various components in addition to catalysts and ion exchange membrane (separator), and each of these components plays a crucial role in determining the performance and durability of the electrolysis cell. Fig. 5 (a) provides a schematic of an electrolysis cell, with each element forming a layered structure. Electrolysis requires the rapid transport of electrons from the current collector to the catalyst layer and ion from the ion exchange membrane to the catalyst layer, which is achieved through a zero-gap structure that eliminates the gap between the electrode and the separator. However, depending on the electrolyte conditions and the applied potential range, an oxide layer can form on the surface of materials. This oxide layer can act as a barrier to electron transport between materials, increase resistance, or induce parasitic currents. Therefore, selecting the appropriate materials and structure is crucial. Ion exchange membranes lack electrical conductivity, but the reason for choosing a direct-contact structure, as previously explained, is to minimize the distance between the two electrodes and maximize the active surface area of the electrochemical catalyst exposed to the electrolyte (ion-exchange membrane). Additionally, by introducing ionomer into the electrode, catalyst utilization and ion conductivity can be enhanced. A porous transport layer (PTL) is used for physical support of the catalytic layer, as well as to facilitate the migration of the reactants (water) and the gaseous products (H2 and O2). If gases generated during electrolysis are not efficiently removed from the electrode surface, they can act as a resistance and significantly reduce electrolysis performance. Therefore, PTLs undergo special surface treatments or possess porous structures like mesh, felt, foam, etc., to facilitate gas detachment. It's known that the type of PTL significantly affects the stability of the bond between the catalyst and PTL, as well as the electrochemical active surface area, which greatly influences performance and durability. Research on catalyst loading methods, the mechanism and suppression of oxide film formation on PTLs is actively underway [14–18] and more details regarding recent researches will be explained in the next sections. Flow fields contain specialized flow patterns within the material and practically supply water from the outside to the PTL and catalyst layer, serving the role of a current collector. Flow patterns affect the transport of reactants and products, influencing overpotential and cell resistance [19]. Common patterns include serpentine or parallel configurations. Lastly, bipolar plates physically compress all the aforementioned components, ensuring appropriate spacing between materials and providing electrical contact with other components while preventing gas/electrolyte leakage. Therefore, bipolar plates must possess sufficient mechanical properties and electrical insulation. Fig. 5(b) illustrates the concept of a stack, which consists of stacking two or more single cells together. An electrolyzer stack is structured by stacking the essential components of a single cell, including the HER electrode, OER electrode, ion-exchange membrane (separator), PTL, and gasket. Unlike a single cell, the flow field in a stack is designed bidirectionally to prevent different electrodes from a short circuit. It also includes insulating spacers to prevent contact between the different electrodes. Fig. 5(c) presents a conceptual diagram of an electrolysis system designed for the substantial production of H2 and O2. To generate high-pressure H2 from water, not only a stack but also various balances of plant (BOP) components are required. Since BOP components make up a significant portion of the overall electrolysis system, understanding them is crucial. Currently, purified water, devoid of microorganisms and other ions, is used as a reactant, so water is pre-treated using a water purifier before being supplied to the stack. Impurities, including microorganisms or precipitate, can foul the internal circulation pipes of the system, stack internal separators, and PTL, leading to a reduction in long-term durability [20]. Additionally, common waterborne metal ions (Fe and Cu) or anions can be adsorbed on catalyst surfaces, potentially affecting catalyst activity and long-term durability [21]. The purified water is transferred to the subsequent stage via gravity or a peristaltic pump. In the case of AWEs, in which 20–30 wt% KOH solution is used as the reactant, an additional step to increase the reactant conductivity through a KOH reservoir is necessary. In the case of SOWEs, a step to convert the reactant into ≥ 200 °C steam is necessary. Subsequently, the voltage applied through the power supply causes the production of O2 and H2 gas at the stack; as each gas contains a small amount of gaseous H2O and KOH, a gas-liquid separation step and a drying step are necessary to obtain pure H2 and O2 gas. Finally, a compressor increases the pressure of the H2 gas, which is transferred to the H2 storage tank. 3 Trends in technological advancement 3.1 Global technological trends The E.U., U.S., and several countries including China and Korea have submitted reports on hydrogen roadmaps through 2035, which indicate the high interest of these countries in water electrolysis systems for hydrogen production. Since 2020, many countries, particularly in Europe and China, have been aggressively investing in water electrolysis systems as shown in Fig. 6 . It is apparent from Table 2 , which compares the operating pressure, H2 production rate, and power consumption, that most of water electrolysis companies providing these specifications officially are located in the EU and US. While AWEs, as the first commercialized systems, have been acquired by many companies, there has been a recent focus on PEMWEs in various emerging companies. In the case of AWEs, most companies are engaged in designing plants for systems, rather than individual components of single cells, and in large-scale hydrogen production, and seek to achieve higher current density based on operation under higher pressure conditions. Depending on the scale of the AWE system, the hydrogen production ranges from 5 to 4,000 Nm3/h. In the case of PEMWEs, as with AWEs, the focus is on system and plant design for large-scale hydrogen production. On the contrary, a few companies are focused on AWMWEs or SOWEs. Based on the reported data, however, SOWEs have the lowest power consumption value around 3.1 kWh/Nm3 compared to others. 3.2 Economic feasibility To achieve a final unit cost of $1/kgH2 in green hydrogen production via water electrolysis, an understanding of the cost of each component in the water electrolysis system is a prerequisite. The necessary costs in the water electrolysis process can be broadly divided into the system cost and electricity cost. Assuming a constant electricity cost, the unit cost of hydrogen production decreases as the cost of the water electrolysis system components decreases. While the unit cost of hydrogen production currently varies according to the type of water electrolysis system, it is known to be the highest for SOWEs (>4 $/kgH2), followed by PEMWEs (>3 $/kgH2) and AWEs (>2 $/kgH2) [4], as each system requires different additional BOP and suitable materials. Fig. 7 presents a cost comparison between PEMWE and AWE systems, as they are the most commercialized systems at present. Fig. 7(a) shows the proportion of each component in a PEMWE system with respect to the total cost; the stack accounts for 45% and the BOP 55%. The bipolar plate and PGM catalysts for each side reaction account for a significant proportion of the total cost [20]. For AWEs, on the other hand, the costs of the catalyst and bipolar plate can be significantly reduced due to the use of non-PGM materials, as shown in Fig. 7(b). In both PEMWE and AWE systems, the BOP accounts for 55% of the total cost, and thus, reducing the cost of each part of the BOP is crucial. Notably, to reduce the cost of the water treatment process, the use of seawater electrolysis, which involves the direct decomposition of seawater, is being investigated, with a focus on AEMWE systems [23–25]. The unit cost of hydrogen production is determined by the normal operation time as well as the costs of the water electrolysis system. As shown in Fig. 7(c), assuming a constant electricity cost, the unit cost of hydrogen production decreases exponentially over time. After operating for more than 4,000 h, the unit cost becomes lower than that of current blue hydrogen production. Therefore, to reduce the unit cost of hydrogen production, an effective water electrolysis system needs to have stability and long-term durability. The water electrolysis stack lifetime in the technical target proposed by the U.S. DOE is 80,000 h (9.13 years) for all types of water electrolysis systems (Table 3 ). In practice, it is not feasible to verify the durability of a water electrolysis cell for 80,000 h. Therefore, accelerated stress tests (AST), which involve repeating specific current densities or voltages based on degradation mechanisms and operating conditions, are used to assess the durability of cells and stacks. Additionally, the extent of degradation can be quantified using the average degradation rate. The technical target suggested by the U.S. DOE includes not only durability but also cell performance, efficiency, and cost. For PEMWEs in particular, it is suggested that the current high unit cost of hydrogen production could be reduced by ensuring high performance and an approximately two-fold longer lifetime while reducing the use of PGM from the current level of 3.0 to 0.125 mg/cm2. In addition to durability, water electrolysis cells should achieve high current density to reduce capital costs and maximize hydrogen production, which would contribute to reducing the unit cost of hydrogen production. Although there are variations depending on the water electrolysis cell type, catalyst composition, and electrode surface area, the average current density of water electrolysis cells ranges from 0.2 to 1.0 A/cm2; ideally, the current density should reach 2–3 A/cm2 at lower voltages. While current density is known to be largely dependent on the electrode catalyst, other components of the water electrolysis cell also have significant impacts. Notably, strong effects arise from heat generation during reactions, gas crossover during operation, cell optimization, and pressure control, and these factors should be considered for developing a suitable cell structure and operating conditions [26]. To sum up, it is crucial to achieve (1) highly stable operation over 80,000 h, (2) reduction of material costs, especially for PGM catalysts and bipolar plates, and (3) a detailed cost breakdown of BOP and electricity for a cost-effective water electrolysis system. In this section, we discuss the main technical challenges associated with each component (catalyst, membrane, PTL, and bipolar plate) for durable operation and introduce recent approaches to overcome these technical limitations. Instead of introducing newly suggested materials, our focus is on benchmarking materials that have been widely used in electrolysis systems, such as the Ir OER catalyst for PEMWE and Zirfon separator for AWE. For PEMWE systems using PGM and Ti plates, which are priced non-competitively, we also discuss strategies for reducing these expensive material usages. We introduce stable operating conditions and a regeneration protocol to explore the possibility of a direct connection between electrolysis and renewable energy sources, considering expected issues like intermittent electricity. 3.2.1 OER catalyst For PEMWE, PGM-based catalysts are widely used as OER catalysts especially, Ir-based catalysts. The projected cost of PEMWE is estimated to be in the range of 1,000–1,400 $/kW with defined strategies to reduce this to 400 $/kW. U. S. DOE aims for a final price point of 150 $/kW to meet the 1 $/kgH2. These goals can be achieved by (1) using a durable catalyst and (2) reducing the PGM amount. Upon simply understanding the Ir degradation mechanism, under OER potential, Ir metal is oxidized to IrO2 while creating soluble Ir3+ and gaseous IrO3 species with severe dissolution (Fig. 8 a) [27]. Although the Ir metal and hydrous Ir oxides, following lattice oxygen participation mechanism (LOM), undergo dissolution through the pathway, they finally create the passivation layer consisting of IrO2, following adsorbate evolution reaction (AEM), with more stable dissolution phenomena than LOM (Fig. 8b–c) [28,29]. From the viewpoint of MEA, it is prone to dissolution of Ir catalyst under high anodic potentials leading to reduced anode current density and overall deterioration in cell performance. Yu et al. investigate PEMWE degradation under low catalyst conditions (0.3 mg/cm2 Pt, 0.08 mg/cm2 Ir) over 4500 h at 1.8 A/cm2. Due to the Ir dissolution to Ir x + and penetration through PEM, Ir migration and re-deposition on the cathode account for 42% of anode catalyst degradation [30]. Based on this mechanism regarding the transformation of Ir to IrO2, the stability of Ir metal can be improved by using a IrO2 thin layer as a passivation layer. Lee et al. introduced the Ir/IrO x core–shell structure as a durable OER catalyst and confirmed low Ir dissolution rate (Fig. 8d) [31]. From the viewpoint of Ir usage amount, commercial PEMWEs utilize high Ir loading (>2 mg/cm2). Although low Ir loading is typically known as a challenging mission due to significant performance/durability reduction [32], reduction of Ir loading can be achieved by adopting new structure of catalyst. Pham et al. developed IrO2-coated TiO2 core-shell microparticles (IrO2@TiO2) synthesized by a facile and scalable method. The catalyst with a loading as low as 0.4 mgIr/cm2 yielded current densities of 1 A/cm2 at 1.67 V [33]. Park et al. developed an IrO2-inverse-opal MEA via the decal-transfer method with the ultra-low catalyst loading of 0.02 mgIr/cm2. It demonstrates a performance 2.5 times superior, achieving 870 mA/cm2 at 1.6 V, compared to that of the conventional MEA [34]. Moreover, extensive research is underway to develop more cost-effective catalysts such as Ru-based OER catalyst due to their affordability, abundant availability, and superior intrinsic activity [35,36]. Yet, its practical application is hindered by poor dissolution resistance under acidic conditions, leading to a short lifespan of just a few hours. To tackle this, researchers have focused on two strategies: (1) incorporating electron-donating elements to reduce Ru's oxidation state and (2) boosting the catalyst's intrinsic activity to lower its operating potential, aiming to prolong its operational life. Wang et al. enhance the activity and stability of Ru-based catalysts for PEMWE by customizing the reaction pathway via MRuO x (M = Ce, Sn, Cr, etc.) solid solutions. Remarkably, the SnRuO x catalyst exhibits exceptional durability and catalytic efficiency, achieving a low voltage degradation rate of 53 μV/h over 1300 h at 1 A/cm2, surpassing both conventional ruthenium-based and certain iridium-based catalysts (Fig. 8e) [37]. For AEMWE and AWE, Ni-based catalysts are widely used as OER catalysts due to their abundance, stability in alkaline media, and state-of-the-art performance. The layered structure of Ni(OH)2 and NiOOH has positive effect on the surface area and mass transport of reactant, while the low conductivity of these Ni species can deteriorate the performance, which is lower even than Ni, Fe, and Co-based spinel structure, under real AEMWE condition [38]. To improve the conductivity, the usage of support material or dopant, which can fill the gap in the valence band, can help. Among the suggested technical targets for cost-effective H2 production, major issue of Ni-based catalysts for alkaline OER is to ensure durability. For high activity, NiFe oxides have widely been studied rather than solely Ni oxide, but the change of OER active site from Ni-O, based on LOM, to Fe atom can cause the rapid degradation of NiFe catalyst. Hence, the activity of NiFe can be changed by the Fe concentration in the electrolyte due to the vacancy formation from Fe dissolution and dynamic exchange of Fe (Fig. 8f and g) [39]. Not only the dissolution of Fe, the irregular formation of Fe oxide (agglomeration) through redeposition process can also deteriorate the stability of NiFe oxide, suggesting that appropriate adsorption energy between Fe and matrix metal (e.g. Ni) is important for the stable operation [39]. To directly inhibit the elution of Fe and the formation of Fe oxides, confirmed by in situ inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) to track Fe dissolution amount, Fe with a low oxidation number was maintained. The OER in alkaline conditions exhibits a marked pH dependence on the anodic current, which activates the redox activity of lattice oxygen [40]. While a high-concentration alkaline electrolyte boosts performance in alkaline-based water electrolysis, use of high concentrated OH− ion, possessing strong nucleophile property, also poses challenges by attacking membranes and ionomers, leading to corrosion and damage. These effects, in turn, compromise the durability and performance of the system [41]. Therefore, when assessing the durability of alkaline water electrolysis, testing at lower alkaline concentrations can be beneficial to mitigate corrosion and damage. Consequently, many studies are aimed at finding a balance between reducing OH− concentration to enhance durability while striving to retain as much of the electrolysis performance as possible [42]. Zhuang et al. address the challenges encountered by AEMWE systems when utilizing non-precious metal catalysts, especially under pure water electrolysis conditions. The authors note that although AEMWE technology permits the use of cost-effective nonprecious metal catalysts, deploying it in pure water-fed scenarios leads to issues in durability. They demonstrate that managing local pH levels by employing buffering agents, such as phosphate buffers, can prevent catalyst reconstruction, thereby improving the durability and performance of AEMWE systems [43]. To mitigate the NiFe degradation phenomenon, we can use (1) dopant to change active site and (2) protecting layer. Hong et al. reported that Ir-doped NiFe oxide (Ir-NFO), where Ir dopant is responsible for OER, showed superior OER stability for 130 h at 100 mA/cm2 (Fig. 8h and i) [44]. As shown in Fig. 8(j and k), the durability of the main catalyst NiFe can also be improved by depositing a protective tetraphenyl porphyrin layer (TPP) on the NiFe surface to prevent the elution of Fe species at the active NiFe sites and suppress the formation of low-conductivity Fe oxides by re-adsorption [45]. 3.2.2 HER catalyst Typically, Pt-based catalysts have been employed within highly acidic environments of PEM systems. Although Pt-based catalysts are at the forefront due to their unmatched properties in hydrogen adsorption and desorption, which are pivotal for optimizing reaction kinetics and overall efficiency, these catalysts bring forth considerations regarding economic feasibility. Hence, researchers have focused on (1) the optimization of dispersion of PGM on support materials to improve catalyst efficiency [46], (2) the enhancement of durability of PGM and support, and (3) the reduction of the usage amount of Pt [47–49]. Carbon-based supports are recognized for their electrical conductivity, expansive surface area, and robust chemical and electrochemical stability. However, their interaction with affixed nanoparticles tends to be minimal, potentially detracting from the overall catalytic efficiency of the composite. This limited interaction does not significantly enhance the intrinsic catalytic activities of the metallic centers. Furthermore, the insubstantial bond between carbon supports and noble metal nanoparticles can result in the migration of these particles across the surface during the HER, leading to potential composite degradation through mechanisms such as particle detachment, aggregation, or coalescence (Fig. 9 a) [50,51]. Innovative carbon structures, distinct in shape, are employed to achieve stable dispersion of catalyst atoms. Song et al. achieved a notable dispersion by embedding single Pt atoms within onion-like carbon (OLC) matrices (Pt1/OLC), thereby anchoring atomically dispersed platinum effectively for use in the HER process. This configuration, compared to the Pt1/graphene setup, showcased superior catalytic activity in 0.5 M H2SO4, maintaining a steady overpotential of 40 mV across a duration of 100 h without any noticeable degradation (Fig. 9b). The exceptional stability of this system is attributed to the robust interaction between the Pt single atoms and the OLC support structure [52]. Similarly, Huang et al. presented the development of Ru nanoclusters anchored on N-doped carbon with abundant micropores, which exhibited remarkable activity across the entire pH spectrum for the HER. The overpotentials observed with the Ru NCs/NC catalyst were notably low, measuring 14 and 30 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm2 in alkaline and neutral conditions, respectively, while demonstrating performance on par with Pt/C in acidic environments [53]. Strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) enhance metal dispersion and stability in catalysts [50,54]. Utilizing SMSI, Yang et al. stabilized Ru nanorods on TiN supports, significantly improving HER performance. These Ru NRs/TiN catalysts displayed low overpotentials of 25 mV at 10 mA/cm2 and a mass activity twenty times higher than conventional Pt/C in alkaline conditions, thanks to SMSI's charge reconfiguration effects. Additionally, they showed remarkable long-term stability, withstanding 10,000 voltammetric cycles without degradation (Fig. 9c) [55]. Recently, MXenes, a new class of two-dimensional materials, have emerged with notable electrical conductivity, hydrophilicity, and reduction capability, streamlining the conversion of metal ions into immobilized nanoparticles. These attributes are particularly advantageous for Pt-group metal electrocatalysts, where both activity and durability are crucial [56,57]. Wang's team has crafted a novel HER catalyst by combining Pt with MXene and single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), resulting in durable, high-performance membranes [58]. Expanding MXene's utility, Nguyen's group has synthesized V-based MXene electrocatalysts, enhancing catalyst-support interactions for improved electron transfer and stability. Their development, featuring Ru clusters on vanadium carbide nanosheets (Ru-Ru2P/V2CT x ), demonstrates strong HER activity across varying pH levels and exhibits exceptional durability in an AEMWE setup (Fig. 9d) [59]. For alkaline HER in AWE and AEMWE, non-PGM catalyst can perform due to their stability in the alkaline media. However, the slower HER kinetics in alkaline media impede the efficiency of alkaline-based water electrolysis systems due to (1) water dissociation, (2) poor water and metal binding energies compared to the hydronium ion (H3O+), and (3) poisoning of active sites by OH− ions, which limits the number of active sites [60]. It is widely known that HER activity trend is strongly influenced by the bond strength between metal and hydrogen (E Me–H) (Fig. 9e). According to this plot, most non-noble catalysts except for Ni and Co are not suitable for HER because they exhibit either weaker Me–H bonds, limiting the adsorption of hydrogen atoms on the free catalytic sites of the electrode, or a strong Me–H bond, which prevents the formation of an H–H bond and the subsequent desorption of produced H2. Hence, researchers have extensively explored Ni and Co as HER catalyst in alkaline media to increase catalytic activity [61,62]. One effective approach has been the development of nanostructured materials with superaerophobic surfaces [63]. Sun et al. synthesized ultrathin 2D Ni-Mo alloy nanosheets through an in situ topotactic reduction of a NiMoO4 precursor (Fig. 9f). Their superaerophobic nanostructured surface further facilitates gas release, significantly boosting HER activity. Additionally, the incorporation of porous structures into HER electrocatalysts has been shown to improve both stability and activity [64–66]. Such structures offer abundant active sites and enhance gas release. Xu et al. developed a nano-dendritic nickel (ND-Ni) catalyst with a three-dimensional microporous structure using the electrodeposition method, leading to a high specific surface area, exceptional conductivity, and hydrophilicity [64]. This catalyst achieved remarkable performance in AWE, maintaining stability over 1000 h in challenging conditions (6 M KOH at 80 °C) (Fig. 9g). Fine-tuning the electronic structure has been another focal point, aiming to minimize the Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption, thereby enhancing catalytic activity and durability [67,68]. Cheng et al. demonstrated this by introducing carbon doping into nanoporous cobalt phosphide (C-Co2P) through electrochemical dealloying, achieving low overpotential and excellent stability in an artificial alkaline seawater electrolyte (Fig. 9h) [67]. This modification tailored the electronic structure of Co2P, facilitating HER through improved water dissociation and hydrogen desorption. Exploring oxygen vacancies/defects as a method of surface reconstruction has also proven fruitful. Such defects influence the adsorption of hydrogen intermediates and the formation and dissociation of water in HER. P. Xi et al. reported the synthesis of S-NiFe2O4 nanomaterials via a low-temperature vulcanization method, introducing sulfur atoms into the oxygen vacancies of NiFe2O4 to enhance active sites and electron transfer capability [69]. This catalyst exhibited exceptional performance and stability in KOH media (61 mV at the current density of 10 mA/cm2 and long-term stability of 60 h at 1.0 A/cm2 in 1.0 M KOH media), with in situ Raman spectroscopy revealing the advantageous formation of S-H* intermediates for hydrogen production. DFT calculation verifies that S introduction lowered the energy barrier of H2O dissociation. 3.2.3 Membrane PEMs in PEMWE play a role in proton transport from anode to cathode. Thanks to the early development of PEMFC, PEMs based on the PFSA structure, such as Nafion, are already commercialized, showing high performance in terms of proton conductivity. Although PEMs are regarded as the weakest components in the PEMWE system, there are insufficient reports on the stability of PEM for PEMWE compared with PEMFC. The harsher operating condition in water electrolyzers than in fuel cells affects the vulnerability in the lifetime of PEMs. For example, a fully hydrated PEM at all times can stress itself through membrane swelling, which can lead to reduced mechanical strength and integrity of the PEMs [71]. To ensure the reliability of PEMs for the cost-effective and prolonged operation of PEMWE, it is essential to understand the main degradation mechanisms of PEMs and some strategies to mitigate the degradation. The degradation mechanisms of PEM in water electrolyzers can be divided into (1) mechanical, (2) chemical, and (3) thermal degradation [72]. Mechanical degradation, meaning crack, tearing, and pinhole formation, usually happens due to failures in the MEA fabrication process [73] and inadequate operating conditions such as too high pressure or humidification. Innovation in the MEA fabrication process and the use of reinforced PEMs can avoid these kinds of mechanical degradation. To reduce the ohmic resistance, thinner PEMs are sometimes recommended, but this approach can be risky, especially in pressurized PEMWE systems, which operate at extremely high pressures around hundreds of bars, due to the mechanical strength and gas crossover issues of the thinner membrane. Recent work from Phan et al. revealed that thin membrane is also unfavorable regarding durability due to pinhole formation from a sharp increase in ohmic resistance (Fig. 10 a–c) [9]. They compared the durability with respect to membrane thickness using NR212 (0.05 mm), N115 (0.127 mm), and N117 (0.178 mm) by applying constant current density of 3 A/cm2 for 144 h and observed pinhole and partially reduced Ir oxide in the anode part due to permeated H2 gas through pinhole [10]. Chemical degradation, considered as main contributor of PEM degradation, results in membrane thinning. Including the PEMFC area, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and its related radical species such as hydroperoxyl (HO2 ) and hydroxyl (HO ), created by the gas crossover between the catalyst layer and membrane or produced as the intermediate species of the OER, attack the ionomer leading to chain scission, unzipping, and loss of functional group [74]. The radical species, produced through Fenton’s reaction occurring under metal cation catalysts (e. g. Fe3+), cause more severe degradation on the membrane [75]. Due to chemical degradation, the membrane's thickness can shrink to 75% during a long-term test, which can lead to an increase in gas crossover [76]. To alleviate the degradation by H2O2-related species, using radical scavenger can help. Choi et al. improved the average degradation rate of PEMWE by using CeO2 to 48 μV/h, which is lower than that of pristine Nafion-based PEMWE (53 μV/h) (Fig. 10d and e) [77]. For a fundamental resolution, the gas crossover phenomenon should be improved not to create H2O2. Lee et al. controlled the hydrophilic channel alignment through the biaxial stretching, leading to the reduction of hydrogen permeability and degradation rate, which is 2.5 times lower than the pristine Nafion sample [78]. The metal cation coming from inlet feeding water or corroded electrolyzer components affects not only membrane thinning but also the proton conductivity of PEM. Metal cation is known to have a higher affinity with SO4 2−, the functional group of PFSA, than with protons, but it has lower mobility than protons leading to high ohmic resistance in PEMWE. However, this degradation can be regenerated by cleaning with acidic electrolytes after operation [79]. Metal nanoparticles/cations from catalyst layer can also contaminate PEMs and the interface between the catalyst layer and membrane [80]. Lastly, thermal degradation is attributed to operating temperature and results in the removal of functional groups in PEMs. It can be mitigated through thermally stable PEMs consisting of polyetheretherketone (PEEK) [81], polysulfone (PSF), and polybenzimidazole (PBI) [82], which allow operation at higher temperatures around 150 °C. Membrane degradation in AEMWE is generally more severe than PEMWE, which typically uses PFSA consisting of strong and stable CF bonds. Since quaternized perfluorinated membrane, like that used in PEM, is not stable in alkaline media, AEM should be based on hydrocarbon polymers with OH− conductivity. This inherent limitation leads to an increase in the ohmic resistance of AEMs (>0.1 Ω cm2) compared to PEMs (0.1 Ω cm2), despite using thinner AEM (20 ∼ 40 μm). AEMWE can be operated with two types of feed water: pure water and concentrated KOH solution. In the case of pure-water-fed AEMWE, the ionomer degradation is the main reason for reduced performance due to the absence of additional electrolyte to transport OH− toward the electrode. This will be discussed in the operating conditions section. This section will focus only on the alkaline stability of AEMs for concentrated KOH electrolyte-fed AEMWE. Hydroxide electrolytes can increase performance and avoid ionomer degradation, but the corrosive property of this caustic material accelerates AEM degradation through (1) chemical reactions by OH−, (2) radical reaction from H2O2, and (3) cross-linking of AEM [83]. Regarding chemical reaction by OH−, the aryl ether backbone structure in AEMs is unstable in alkaline media due to aryl ether cleavage reaction [84,85]. For the cationic functional group, it was revealed that benzyl ammonium cation degrades rapidly through nucleophilic substitution reaction by OH−. To prevent this reaction, studies have been conducted to replace the aryl ether-based backbone and benzyl ammonium cation with alternative structures like alkyl piperidinium and bulky imidazolium [86–89]. Moreover, PBI, used for high-temperature PEMWE, can be a solution for stable AEMWE operation. Under extremely high alkaline media (6 M KOH at 85 °C), PBI showed no chemical structural change for 176 days [89]. On the other hand, not only in PEMWE but also in AEMWE, H2O2-related radical reactions pose serious problems. When AEM is exposed to Fenton’s test, surface cracking is observed, suggesting AEM dissolution due to the loss of OCH3 (Fig. 10f) [90]. Additionally, the radical can directly attack the aromatic rings under high pH conditions [91]. Lastly, basic conditions can lead to gel formation by cross-linking of AEM. Unintended cross-linking results in adverse changes to AEM properties, such as decreasing water uptake and OH− conductivity [83]. Durability tests for AEMs were conducted for up to 1000 h at a constant current density below 1 A/cm2, despite massive initial cell performance [92–94]. Recently, Moreno-Gonźalez et al. reported a one-year operation result (8900 h) using a commercial membrane (Aemion+) exhibiting negligible change in OH− conductivity and low H2 crossover under 0.4% (Fig. 10h) [95]. The separator for AWE has a quite different shape from that of PEMWE and AEMWE, which use ion-selective exchange membranes. The small pores in the AWE separator allow the exchange of OH− ions by transferring electrolytes between the electrodes. Typically, a composite consisting of zirconia and thermoplastic polysulfone is widely used as a stable separator for AWE. This combination, adding hydrophilic ceramic material as a filler, has been suggested to resolve the hydrophobic properties of the polymer [96]. In the case of the commercial separator known as Zirfon PERL UTP 500 (ionic conductivity = 0.3 Ω cm2 in 30 wt% KOH), the thickness and pore diameter have been reported as 500 μm and 0.15 μm, respectively. Although this porous separator has much higher durability than those in PEM and AEM systems, the existence of pores prevents operation at high working pressure by causing huge gas crossover [97,98], which is the biggest bottleneck for high-performance AWE systems. Schalenbach et al. found that the hydrogen diffusivity of the commercial separator is approximately 16% of the electrolyte filling inside the pore (Fig. 10g) [99]. The convection of cross-permeated electrolyte causes hydrogen crossover, suggesting the requirement of small pores for low gas permeability and operation at high working pressures. Large pores are also disadvantageous in terms of dynamic operation conditions, especially when operating at low current density regions, indicating difficulty in connecting intermittent renewable energy sources and AWE. To mitigate the issue of gas crossover through the separator, Lee et al. controlled the ratio of zirconia and polysulfone and achieved a high bubble point pressure of 3.8 bar, which is higher than that of commercial Zirfon PERL (2.5 bar) [100]. When the ceramic filler material is altered to TiO2, the bubble point pressure can reach 3 bar while exhibiting a cell voltage of 2.1 V at 2.0 A/cm2 for 1000 h (Fig. 10i) [101]. Functionalized zirconia can also obtain high AWE performance by increasing the wettability of the Zirfon separator [102]. Surface modification to reduce pore diameter can mitigate the gas crossover problem. Kim et al. blocked the surface of a commercial Zirfon separator by spray-coating crosslinked polyvinyl alcohol, resulting in a decrease in pore diameter and hydrogen permeability without significant resistance change [103]. 3.2.4 PTL Due to the highly corrosive environment, Ti-based PTLs have been commonly used in PEMWE systems in forms of Ti felt, mesh, foam, sintered particles, and engineered thin films, as shown in Fig. 11 (a) [104,105]. Owing to its stability and anti-corrosive properties in acidic media, Ti metal is known as a benchmarking material for PEMWE PTL [91]. However, in the presence of oxygen, Ti naturally forms a thin oxide layer (3–10 nm) on Ti metal over time due to high cell overpotential and OER. The oxide layer can help prevent corrosion of Ti metal by acting as a passivation layer, but its semi-conductive property can impede electrical conduction toward the catalyst layer. In fact, the broken electrical connection due to the existence of a native oxide layer has been focused on as the principal reason for the reduction of performance and durability in PEMWE. Doo et al. revealed that the electron transport problem in the native oxide layer causes poor performance of ultralow-IrO x -loaded MEA due to upward band bending by Schottky contact between a metallic conductor (IrO x ) and semiconductor (TiO x ) (Fig. 11b) [15]. Apart from requiring high cell voltage for operating a single cell due to native oxide, it leads to significant degradation of the catalyst layer. Rakousky et al. investigated the durability of PEMWE using MEA with Ti PTL for just over 1000 h. They observed a significant degradation rate of 194 μV/h. This degradation was primarily attributed to the increase in ohmic resistance, predominantly caused by detectable degradations affecting the anodic Ti PTL [106]. After 4000 h of operation, agglomerated Ir catalyst residuals were found on untreated Ti felt, indicating detachment of the catalyst layer from PTL [14]. Similarly, the formation of voids and cracks was found in MEA using untreated Ti PTL after a long-term durability test [17]. These results imply that the formation of the native oxide layer should be avoided for stable PEMWE operation. Hence, some surface treatment strategies for Ti PTL have been suggested such as acidic treatment for removal of the native oxide layer [96,107], coating with a thin PGM layer (Au, Pt, and Ir) (Fig. 11c) [14,17,108,109], and introduction of second atoms (H, C, and Nb) into Ti [110–112]. Furthermore, the usage of a microporous layer on Ti PTL can help improve durability by facilitating the mass transport of oxygen through the PTL [113]. Among these approaches, the utilization of a thin Pt or Ir layer is widely used to improve durability, but it still has the disadvantage of reduced-price competitiveness due to using PGM. To reduce the amount of Pt coating, Liu et al. attempted to figure out the optimal pattern of Pt coating with gaps on Ti PTL [114]. However, the small gap still impacted durability by exposing Pt-uncoated regions, which can lead to the dissolution of ionomer and growth of TiO x . In fact, not only PGM coating, but Ti also contributes to the cost increase of PEMWE. Hence, Becker et al. assessed the potential profile in a water electrolyzer to minimize the use of Ti and revealed that the corrosive zone extended only ∼ 200 μm into the PTL from the catalyst layer [115]. They opened the possibility of substitution of Ti PTL with abundant materials like stainless steel (SS) [116]. Stiber et al. suggested SS-based PTL for PEMWE. Since stainless steel is not stable in PEMWE operating conditions, they introduced Nb/Ti as a coating layer onto SS, allowing for an increased current density over 13 times [117]. Interestingly, Nb/Ti on SS PTL endured AST over 1000 h without any sign of Fe contamination in both membrane and electrode (Fig. 11d–e). Apart from the selection of material study for PEMWE, the distribution of product and heat at high current density is an important issue in PEMWE, which can be operated at the highest current density (normally 1–3 A/cm2 and up to 20 A/cm2) among other electrolysis technologies [118]. Although relatively low current region (0.01 to 2 A/cm2) and pressure do not affect the distribution of water and gas in PTL [119], at these high current densities, stagnation can start to show the critical current and further limit current due to mass transport limitation. Through operando neutron imaging setup, Lee et al. demonstrated that product gases are uniformly distributed in PTL adjacent to the catalyst layer and this makes local hot-spots at higher current densities like 7 and 9 A/cm2, where the critical current density in gas saturation profile begins to show (Fig. 11f) [120]. It can cause undesired degradation from non-uniform current density and temperature distribution [121], suggesting the use of PTL with effective gas removal properties to stably operate at high current density. Compared to PEMWE, choices of PTL for AWE and AEMWE broaden due to the high pH environment. Most transition metals are stable by existing in the form of metal or metal hydroxide/oxide at the HER and OER potential. Carbon materials were utilized as PTL for short-term performance evaluation, but carbon is much more vulnerable to electrochemical degradation in alkaline media than in acidic media. Although it is known that the kinetics of carbon oxidation (C + 2H2O → CO2 + 4H+ + 4e−, E 0 = 0.207 VSHE, C + H2O → CO + 2H+ + 2e−, E 0 = 0.518 VSHE) is very slow [122], the reaction mechanism can alter by the electrolyte pH. Acid catalyzes ring-opening in the graphitic substrate leading to the oxidation in the bulk phase, while abundant OH radicals in alkaline media tend to react with the alkyl site, leading to the oxidation of the edge site and finally resulting in dissolution [123]. Hence, Ni-based material and stainless steel comprising alloys of Ni, Fe, Mo, and Cr are typical PTL for water electrolyzers in the alkaline medium as a form of mesh, paper, felt, and foam. Similarly to Ti PTL in PEMWE, the passivating property of Cr in stainless steel for improved corrosion resistance can hinder the electrochemical reaction. Many researchers have suggested surface modification methods to remove inactive Cr-related species [124]. As Ni and Fe in stainless steel are OER active species, they can be used as the catalyst itself through a self-activation mechanism. Tricker et al. demonstrated that a stainless steel PTL-electrode fabricated by electro-activation showed high stability (AEMWE operation at 2 A/cm2 over 600 h) with an extremely small degradation rate of 5 μV/h (Fig. 11g) [125]. Other factors such as porosity, shape, surface area in contact with the catalyst/membrane [16], and fiber diameter [126] significantly affect electrolysis performance and long-term stability. Park et al. compared Ti paper, SUS paper, and Ni foam in terms of the AEMWE performance and voltage degradation rate [16]. SUS paper showed the highest performance and the lowest degradation rate (15 mV/h) due to its well-structured metal fiber surface providing a larger contact area than Ni foam with a curved surface (Fig. 11h). The use of Ni-based microporous layer (MPL) fabricated by a plasma gun method was also suggested for AEMWE operating in pure water. [127]. 3.2.5 Bipolar plate As one of the core components in a water electrolyzer, the bipolar plate provides mechanical support to PTL and catalyst layer, distributes reactant water inside the cell, and transports the product gas to the outlet channel. We need to consider optimal flow field pattern in the bipolar plate. Generated heat mal-distribution due to an insufficient heat transfer rate can cause a sudden rise in local temperature, leading to degradation of MEA [128]. Void areas created by trapped bubbles in the flow field can block the active electrode surface, significantly increasing overpotential and degrading the performance and subsequently the lifetime of PEMWE [129–131]. Typically, flow fields can be divided into five types: pin, parallel, serpentine, interdigitated, and cascade (Fig. 12 a) [130]. Depending on the flow type design, pressure, and fluid removal rates change. The single serpentine type is commonly used for small-area the applications due to the advantage of high velocity in the flow channel, but there are still issues such as reactant depletion along the length of the channel, pressure drop, and flooding danger at the high current density. For stable operation at high current density and large cell area, optimal flow channel design should be suggested through three-dimensional modeling and demonstration [132]. In the case of PEMWE, the harsh environment on the anode side (high temperature = 60–80 °C, electrolyte pH = 1–4, high working potential = 1–2 V) and the requirement of stable long-term operation narrows the range of material choices. Typically, high-purity Ti (grade 2), presenting challenges in cost and machining, is widely regarded as suitable for the bipolar plate due to its corrosion-resistance behavior and adequate mechanical strength. As with the PTL case, the formation of a Ti oxide layer can seriously reduce the conductivity and hydrogen production performance in long-term operation. A thin layer coating with PGMs such as Pt and Au has been used to cover the bipolar plate to eliminate the conductivity issue caused by Ti passivation [133]. On the other hand, Ti suffers from hydrogen embrittlement in HER part, which is vulnerable in long-term operation [134]. Ti tends to absorb hydrogen over 1000 ppm, leading to the destruction of its mechanical properties in terms of tensile strength and ductility. To avoid this, Au can be used as a coating material to prevent hydrogen absorption [135]. However, these approaches have made the price of bipolar plates account for 40%–60% of the total stack cost. To reduce the bipolar plate cost, we need to overcome the technical and cost challenges of PGM-coated Ti by replacing the coating and core material with alternatives offering high corrosion/chemical resistance, high through-plane electrical conductivity, and low interfacial contact resistance (ICR). For coating materials instead of Au and Pt, layered structures consisting of metal and metal nitride (TiN, TaN, ZrN, CrN, and NbN) or with metal carbide (TiN-C) have been actively studied [136–138]. Ye et al. compared the ICR of three metal nitride coatings on Ti metal and demonstrated the lowest ICR value can be achieved using Ta/TaN coating (3.9 Ω cm2), a reduction of 74% compared to pristine Ti metal (14.9 Ω cm2) [136]. Meanwhile, Lædre et al. compared various non-coated metal plates as bipolar plates in PEMWE in terms of current density by corrosion reaction and oxide formation and ICR change during stability tests (Fig. 12b) [139]. Ta, Nb, and Ti showed high corrosion resistance with low current density and mass change, but Ta and Nb showed a significant increment of ICR due to the formation of a surface oxide layer during prolonged CA tests at 2.0 V. Stainless steel samples (304 L and 316 L) and W showed minor corrosion behavior due to their OER activity, but they require some modification to fulfill the requirement of a bipolar plate for PEMWE. Hence, stainless steel is regarded as a substitute for Ti metal in PEMWE due to its abundance and ease of machining, but extremely low pH can cause the dissolution of stainless steel, resulting in the deterioration of MEA performance in long-term operation [52]. A recent study from Fiedler et al., however, demonstrated that stainless steel 316 L notably degrades, showing a high dissolution rate measured by scanning flow cell setup coupled to an inductively coupled plasma spectrometer, but contamination in a full cell is estimated under 1 ppm (Fig. 12c) [140]. Becker et al. also advocated the use of carbon-coated stainless steel as a bipolar plate rather than Ti, as there was no evidence of degradation of stainless steel even after testing for 30 days at 2 A/cm2 [115]. These studies suggest the viability of stainless steel as a core material for bipolar plate in PEMWE if there is a covering material to retard the continuous dissolution due to the absence of a passivation layer on stainless steel. To find the optimal coating material for stainless steel, Rojas et al. prepared various surface-coated (CrN/TiN, Ti/TiN, Ti, and TiN) stainless steel via physical vapor deposition and evaluated their corrosion behavior [116]. After examining corrosion behavior considering weight loss, dissolved metal amount, and surface change, they found Ti/TiN layer has the best stability and ICR value after the corrosion test (9.9 mΩ cm2) (Fig. 12d). Not only TiN but numerous studies dealing with various metal nitride, metal alloys, and even conductive polymers have been reported to enable the utilization of stainless steel as a bipolar plate in PEMWE [141,142]. Interestingly, Stiber et al. tested the long-term stability of Nb-coated stainless-steel bipolar plates for 14000 h, which operated with only 5.5 μV h−1 average degradation rate (operating at 1.9 V while maintaining 1 A/cm2) (Fig. 12e) [143]. Even though Nb created poorly conductive amorphous Nb oxide, it did not affect the PEMWE cell performance, suggesting the possibility of a complete substitution of Ti with covered stainless steel bipolar plates. Cu is also considered as a substitute for Ti metal, but it requires a 30 μm thick Nb metal layer to prevent Cu corrosion [144]. Similar to the PTL case, water electrolyzer operating in alkaline medium (AEMWE and AWE) have more freedom in choosing materials for the bipolar plate. Ni [145] and stainless steel, including Ti [146,147], are widely used as bipolar plates for AEMWE and AWE. Compared to Ti which has high resistance due to the passivating oxide layer (600 mA/cm2 at 2.8 V), Ni showed stable operation for 5000 h with low cell resistance and voltage (600 mA/cm2 at 1.8 V) [95]. In the case of commercial AWE running at the largest scale compared to other electrolyzer technologies, it is crucial to analyze the uniform distribution of temperature and reactant/product for higher current density and stability. Hence, AWE typically uses three types of bipolar plates including expanded mesh, concave-convex plates, and machined flow fields (Fig. 12f) [148]. Research has been focusing on computational fluid dynamics (CFD) numerical simulations for realistic operation, such as commonly used concave-convex bipolar plates [149–151]. 3.2.6 Operating condition Operating condition includes flow rate, temperature, cell pressure, and way of applying voltage/current. All of these factors significantly affect cell performance and further long-term durability, so it is crucial to optimize the operating condition to improve the cell performance using limited material cost. Most PEMWE operation is performed at current densities of 2 A/cm2 at 2 V in single cell scale, which is still insufficient for cost-effective hydrogen production. The U.S. DOE suggests operating at a much higher current density at a lower voltage (3.0 A/cm2 @ 1.6 V/cell) in a stack as the ultimate target, achievable through optimization of operating conditions. For PEMWE, the operating temperature is typically set in the range of 60–80 °C. Choi et al. examined the temperature effect of current density with the same MEA and observed that cell performance slightly increased with increasing temperature due to improvement in ionic conductivity and reduction in activation energy [152]. As temperature increases, thermodynamic voltage for electrolysis decreases, leading to improved efficiency [153] since the thermodynamic voltage of water electrolysis can be reduced by around < 8.5 mV per 10 °C [147]. However, increasing the temperature above 100 °C, the boiling point at ambient pressure, is challenging due to electrolyte vaporization, dehydration of the membrane, and further reduction in proton conductivity [154]. To counteract high-temperature issues, the utilization of phosphorus acid doped [155] Nafion-silica membrane [156] can be an option, but pressurization of PEMWE can also solve the membrane dehydration issues by raising the boiling temperature [154,157]. Lee et al. operated a single cell at high temperature (90 and 120 °C) and high pressure (1 to 2.5 bar) and achieved 8.3 A/cm2 at 2 V with an electrodeposited Ir anode with only a loading amount of 0.1 mg/cm2 [158]. However, an imbalance between temperature and pressure, especially a higher temperature than saturated temperature at the operating pressure, decreases liquid saturation, leading to water shortage. Kai et al. proposed guidelines for pressurized PEMWE at high temperatures, suggesting that increasing the temperature from 100 to 120 °C and raising the pressure from 0.13 to 0.22 MPa can prevent the gas saturation from exceeding 0.3 [159]. This adjustment allows for a lower electrolysis voltage, varying from 1.57 to 1.51 V. Nonetheless, these conditions are insufficient from an industrial viewpoint. Much higher operating pressure, around 10–150 bar, is pivotal to get rid of mechanical hydrogen compressors, which are frequently used for compressing produced hydrogen gas and accounts for more than half of total CAPEX (Capital expenditure) in hydrogen refueling stations [22,160]. According to Marangio et al., PEMWE operation at a pressure about 30–45 bar lowers the required energy compared to atmospheric electrolysis plus additional compression [155]. Therefore, most commercial PEMWE systems have been adopting high-pressure operation around 40 bar, with a range of specific energy consumption of 3.5–5 kWh/Nm3 [22]. However, operation at high pressure (10 ∼ 150 bar) can induce severe degradation (e.g. membrane creep [72], metal embrittlement by hydrogen) and safety issue regarding gas cross-over through diffusion by electro-osmotic drag force and partial pressure difference between cathode and anode [161]. In the case of gas crossover, the concentration of hydrogen in oxygen generated at the anode and that of oxygen in hydrogen generated at the cathode both raise with elevated temperature and pressure [9,162]. This is attributed to the increased solubility and mobility of gases in the membrane, presenting potential hazards. To mitigate these challenges caused by high-pressure operation, employing alternative material for PFSA membrane [163] and innovation in the MEA manufacturing process for even mechanical compression and protection of membrane edges could help [164]. Apart from optimizing operating condition for cell performance measured by the I-V curve, one important factor is prolonged lifetime with a low degradation rate. The ultimate goal of PEMWE is operation for 80,000 h (=9.13 year) with an average degradation rate of 2.0 mV/kh (=2 μV/h). Until now, there is no clear guideline for measuring lifetime and degradation rate, but these factors are significantly influenced by applied current density/voltage and operation method (e.g. applying constant or dynamic current [165,166]. Rakousky et al. compared degradation behavior under operation with constant and intermittent current (Fig. 13 a) [165]. MEA operated at constant high current (2 A/cm2) showed the highest degradation rate of 194 μV/h, but this value reduced when they operated through the intermittent profile (2 and 0 A/cm2, 10 min each) due to recovering reversible part of degradation. Furthermore, Papakonstantinou et al. observed a mild kinetic degradation rate of only 2.6 μV/h through dynamic operation, mimicking fluctuating and intermittent renewable energy sources due to the crystallization of Ir rather than dissolution and redeposition onto ionomer (Fig. 13b and c) [167]. Compared to kinetic degradation, irreversible degradation regarding ohmic resistance was more significant. They also observed recovered performance of the MEA through cathodic sweep, indicating Ir might go through reversible degradation and its activity can be regenerated by creating Ir sites with lower valence [168]. It means that more diverse operation protocol is needed to check MEA durability in terms of reversible and irreversible degradation for long-term operation. Like PEMFC, to simulate the degree of degradation for around one decade, AST protocols have been developed by EU projects based on a deep understanding of material/component degradation (especially irreversible degradation of anodic catalyst dissolution [169–171], degradation of membrane/ionomer, and TiO x formation) and stressors [172]. Aßmann et al. proposed essential protocols that should be included in the AST protocol: (1) nominal current density, (2) high current density operation, (3) load cycling, and (4) OCV or shut-down process [172]. Protocols (1) and (2) typically induce degradation on the anode side, while protocols (3) and (4) cause degradation of cathode part due to corrosion of the Pt/C carbon support and agglomeration of Pt nanoparticles (Fig. 13d and e) [173]. Lastly, the effect of impurities from feeding water or material/tubing line corrosion is not negligible in PEMWE long-term operation [79,174]. Metal cations such as Na+, Mg2+, and Ca2+, which can enter the system by unpurified water (e.g. sea water and portable water), lower conductivity of membrane and ionomer and have a negative effect on catalytic activities of both sides. Halide ions from water purification failures can enhance dissolution and induce unintended side products through chlorine ion oxidation reactions. In case of AWE, which is the most mature technology, operating conditions have been established through extensive research to reduce the power consumption and improve efficiency. Industrial AWE electrolyzers use KOH electrolytes with a concentration of 30 wt% and are usually operated at a temperature range of 60 to 90 °C. The operating pressure is around 3.2 MPa. The initial design of AWE has a significant gap between the electrodes, but the development of gas separators such as Zirfon has enable operation of zero-gap AWE system. This allows for a decrease in cell voltage by releasing created bubbles from the backside of the electrode, significantly reducing resistance [175]. Haverkort et al. suggested 0.2 mm as the optimal electrode gap for efficient AWE operation by eliminating ohmic loss from bubbles [176]. The use of a gas separator can also increase cell pressure, thereby reducing bubble coverage on the electrode and bubble resistance [177]. Ahn et al. studied the optimal operating pressure by subsequently increasing cell pressure and suggested 4.1 MPa as the optimal condition to achieve the lowest cell voltage value in I-V curve [178]. Since water splitting is endothermic reaction, increasing the operating temperature can directly not only decrease the thermodynamic reversible voltage and activation overpotential but also affect total efficiency through indirect influence on energy efficiency, water activity, and electrolyte conductivity [179,180]. Ding et al. revealed that increasing temperature is beneficial for improving electrolytic efficiency, but it can cause additional energy requirements from the perspective of the total energy use in the whole electrolyzer system [177,181]. Despite these numerous studies to improve AWE performance, the operating current density range is from 0.2 to 0.7 A/cm2 [182], which is significantly lower than other electrolyzer systems. Furthermore, according to DOE technical targets, the current density for AWE should be achieved to 2.0 A/cm2 @ 1.7 V/cell for cost-effective hydrogen production. A recent study from Jang et al. achieved 1.0 A/cm2 @ 1.74 V at 120 °C and the highest efficiency of 78.52 % under 10 bar and 1 A/cm2 at 120 °C. They stressed the pressurized operation at high temperature for high performance and the possibility of gas crossover (Fig. 13f) [183]. Similar to PEMWE, the effects of intermittent operation on AWE durability for further connection with renewable energy have been extensively investigated [184,185]. Haleem et al. studied the reverse current phenomenon that occurs after shutdown due to redox reaction of the electrode and bipolar plate, which potentially reduces the lifetime [186]. The reverse current phenomenon can expose cathodes with large charge capacities to corrosion; therefore, they recommended stopping electrolyte circulation immediately after the operation finishes. Beyond the single cell and stack scale, some researchers have been expanding the area of optimization studies toward kW and MW-scale systems. Although the main power-consuming component in the system is the water electrolyzer, the power consumption of BOP accounts for 20% of the supplied energy due to losses in the form of overpotential and heat production [187]. By examining the energy flow of 250 kW AWE under steady and cold start processes, Ding et al. revealed that constant voltage control can reduce the cold start time compared with constant current mode, and that reducing the thermal capacity of system component can also cut down the cold start time to less than 1 h (Fig. 13g) [188]. For AEMWE, the ultimate goal for performance and durability has not been announced yet, but there have been significant developments regarding these two factors. AEMWE current density at 2 V, regarded as one of bottleneck for commercialization, is typically under 1 A/cm2 [189]. Recently, impressive current densities of 7.68 A/cm2 have been reported due to the rapid development of AEMs [92]. To achieve the best performance and stability in AEMWE, optimization of operating conditions should proceed. In terms of temperature, AEMWE has an optimal operating temperature range of 50 ∼ 85 °C, similar to PEMWE and AWE, but it tends to avoid higher temperatures higher than 70 °C due to the low thermal stability of AEMs [190]. Furthermore, unlike PEMWE, pressurized cell operation does not improve cell performance [191], but pressurizing AEMWE to 8.5 bar can help to reduce the humidity of produced H2, suggesting a reduction of BOP to dry the produced H2 gas. However, increasing pressure up to 10 bar can cause gas cross-over [192]. The selection of feeding water for AEMWE is a hot issue compared to PEMWE and AWE, which use relatively designated liquid electrolytes like DI water and high-concentrated KOH solution. In the early stage of AEMWE development, high-concentration KOH electrolytes (e.g. 30 wt% KOH [193]) were used to compensate for the low OH− ion conductivity of AEMs. To become a cost-effective technology, various electrolytes such as pure water, 1 M or 0.1 M KOH, 1 wt% K2CO3 have been widely studied [44,127,189,194–200]. The performance in pure-water-fed AEMWE, the most desired solution to significantly reduce the BOP regarding electrolyte system, is still less than that of other feeding waters due to the insufficient ion conductivity of ionomer and membrane. The conductivity of AEM under 1 M KOH is 57.4 mS/cm, while the hydroxide conductivity in pure-water-fed conditions is only 18.4 mS/cm, which is five times less than in the 1 M KOH condition. This indicates much lower catalyst utilization due to reduced catalyst-electrolyte interfacial area, resulting in higher performance of 1 M KOH-fed AEMWE compared to pure-water and 1 wt% K2CO3-fed systems [83]. Not only does the feeding solution influence performance, but it also affects the durability of AEMWEs [83]. For pure-water-fed AEWME, Zheng et al. recently demonstrated the stability of the system with only Ni-based catalysts for both electrodes operating at 1 A/cm2 over 550 h. The average degradation rate was 71 μV/h with cell voltage setting around 1.82 V in pure water [200]. Stable operation at 1 A/cm2 using a 1 M KOH electrolyte and PGM-free catalysts was possible over 12000 h with an average degradation rate of 0.7 μV/h [201]. The relatively low stability of pure-water-fed AEMWE is attributed to ionomer detachment from the catalyst surface and ionomer poisoning due to the absence of additional electrolyte [83], and reduced catalytic activity/stability in neutral bulk pH, while the stability of 1 M KOH-fed AEMWE can be reduced through membrane degradation by abundant OH− and catalyst degradation, as we already discussed in an earlier section. Although there are no suggested technical requirements for AEMWE regarding durability, we estimate it will be similar to other electrolysis systems, around 80,000 h. Most of the durability test protocols have been conducted by applying a constant current density to define the average voltage increment value by degradation. Not only voltage behavior showing a gradual in cell voltage over time indicate degradation, but other behaviors such as rapid performance decay can occur depending on situations (e.g. catalytic activity loss, gas crossover, mechanical failure of AEM) [83]. Similar to PEMWE, studies on the effect of stationary/dynamic operation on AEMWE durability are ongoing. Niaz et al. compared the degradation behavior for 1000 h under two different potentiostatic modes (Fig. 13h–j) [202]. Long periodic operation, which is regarded as a relatively stationary mode, showed better stability due to the maintenance of ohmic/non-ohmic resistance during the test. They also studied the effect of on-off cycling on AEMWE stability, demonstrating that stability can be maintained under continuous KOH solution flow by avoiding an irreversible increase in ohmic and polarization resistance [203], while abnormally high negative/positive current by switching between 2.1 and 0 V detrimentally affected cell stability mainly due to anode catalyst detachment [204]. 3.2.7 Connecting water electrolysis with renewable energy sources Typically, water electrolyzers can be connected to photovoltaic and wind power generation systems, which are widely deployed around the world. However, the amount of hydrogen produced strongly depends on the geographic location and weather conditions, leading to significant fluctuations by date, time, and season (Fig. 14 a and b). These patterns do not follow a general pattern such as a Gaussian distribution; therefore, some researchers have been focusing on understanding these fluctuation patterns through machine learning. Moreover, the amplitude of fluctuation can be reduced by using a smoothing method that expands the area of the power plant source [205]. The final aim of producing green hydrogen is to operate water electrolyzers with renewable energy. However, most current water electrolyzers are not suited to be operated by this fluctuating energy source. A high reverse current due to the repetitive on/off cycle operation causes oxidation of the cathode and reduction of the anode, which triggers serious problems in terms of the long-term durability of the electrolyzer system, as discussed in the earlier section. Fortunately, this reverse current issue can be mitigated by the sudden stop of electrolyte flow and reduction of reducible metal amount in the system [186]. By reducing the number of stop cycle operations, the efficiency of water electrolysis can also be improved by an additional 6.3% when photovoltaic power is incorporated [206]. From a catalyst perspective, sacrificial materials such as Mn at the HER can alleviate the degradation of the cathode by the oxidation reaction from reverse current [144]. Despite the rapid current response property due to by high proton conductivity of PEMs, PEMWE cannot be free from degradation induced by abrupt operating conditions such as on/off cycles. As shown in the earlier section, the durability of PEMWE is strongly dependent on the operating condition [165]. As a regeneration process, controlled dynamic operation can recover the durability of PEMWE under a renewable energy source. 4 Future of water electrolysis 4.1 Recommended research directions Ultimately, to achieve a hydrogen-based net-zero carbon emission society, clean hydrogen must be produced at a long-term affordable price without CO2 emissions (Hydrogen Shot (111); Aim to consistently produce 1 kg of clean H2 gas for $1 over the span of a decade). To accomplish this goal, not only advanced water electrolysis technologies but also carbon-free electrical power generation technologies from renewable and nuclear energy sources must be secured.
