Efficient integration with water electrolysis is crucial. With renewable energy, power generation can be irregular and subject to weather and time variations. To maintain high hydrogen production efficiency under these power conditions, it is necessary to establish a water electrolysis system with comprehensive operating conditions [207] as mentioned in the earlier part. Additionally, water electrolysis cells and stack components that satisfy the performance, durability, and precious-metal-use criteria of the previously described technical target must be developed. As increases in performance lead to increased hydrogen production per unit area, the volume of the water electrolysis system itself could be reduced to lower the cost of the BOP as well as the use of cell and stack components. So far, numerous studies have reported on the individual development and real-time analysis of individual cellular components, but few have investigated the performance and long-term durability of actual large-scale cells or stacks. With respect to catalyst development, the actual single-cell environment differs from the half-cell environment used for analyzing the catalytic performance in terms of pH, pressure, and temperature conditions; hence, the catalyst performance and durability may differ [208]. It is thus essential to monitor the performance and durability when a novel material is applied in an actual cell, and techniques to analyze changes inside cells according to operation time (changes in electrical conductivity, catalyst elution, etc.) should be developed based on real-time optical analysis of cells and stacks [209]. Through these analyses, the thermal degradation behavior under actual operating conditions could be determined, and ways to improve the lifetime could be identified. 4.2 Recommended research directions Broadly speaking, hydrogen has been utilized in the chemical and manufacturing industries, and as an energy carrier. The global demand for hydrogen as of 2022 is 22 Mt/year (Mt: Metric Tons), with the demand so far mostly arising in the refining sector (Fig. 15 ). High demand has also continued in the fields of ammonia and methanol production and steel production, but the demand for hydrogen in other fields, including as an energy carrier, has represented less than 0.1%of the total. The demand for hydrogen as an energy carrier is predicted to increase markedly by more than 150% by 2030 due to the expansion of infrastructure, with the level increasing to 10 MMt/year (MMt: Million Metric Tons) by 2030, 20 MMt/year by 2040, and 50 MMt/year by 2050. According to the U.S. DOE, the demand for hydrogen as an energy carrier for vehicles is predicted to increase to 8 Mt/year, mainly for use in medium-duty vehicles (4,500–11,700 kg, e.g., delivery trucks and small trucks) and heavy-duty vehicles (>11,700 kg., e.g., large trucks and construction equipment) rather than in light-duty vehicles such as consumer cars. Additionally, the demand for hydrogen in energy storage systems for the storage and supply of residual energy from new renewable energy is predicted to reach 8 Mt/year. In South Korea, there are currently 162 hydrogen refueling stations, which represents a high level compared to other countries (164 in Japan and 86 in the U.S. as of 2022), so the use of hydrogen as an energy carrier appears to be feasible. Furthermore, to ensure the safe supply of hydrogen, the safety criteria are being formulated and applied to various water electrolysis systems, including high-voltage stacks and SOWEs, which are in development. Hydrogen is the fuel with the highest energy-density on Earth, as well as an energy carrier with the potential for abundant production and use in various special environments, such as space [210]. The European Space Agency (ESA) has already developed a high-pressure steam electrolyser for exploration surface missions [211]. Additionally, Russia has recently introduced the concept of a universal space platform with a propulsion system based on water electrolysis [212]. In particular, a PEMWE-based water electrolysis device was loaded on a space probe and successfully achieved high propulsion through gas combustion despite the limited weight of the probe (Fig. 16 ). A water electrolysis device can be loaded on a small probe of less than 100 kg; the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) will soon launch an empirical test in this area. However, outer space has different temperatures (−273–100 °C), pressure (0–600 Pa), and gravity conditions than Earth, and thus, to ensure normal operation of water electrolysis devices, complementary techniques are required. Furthermore, the impact of gamma rays in outer space cannot be ignored, as they are known to be 200–1,000 times stronger than the natural radiation on earth. The effects of radiation on the materials inside the water electrolysis system should therefore be reviewed. While various studies have explored the effects of radiation on polymers such as PTFE [213], further studies should investigate its effects on PFSA and DVB, which are the main materials of ion exchange membranes. Moreover, for Pt, one of the main catalysts in water electrolysis systems, the Pt vacancies mediated by neutron rays lead to structural collapse; stainless steel is likewise known to experience particle cracking [214]. To ensure the durability of the catalyst and the components of the water electrolysis system (end plate, PTL, etc.), a radiation shielding technique is necessary. 5 Perspective and conclusions With global efforts underway to develop hydrogen utilization in response to climate change, the demand for water electrolysis systems to ensure a stable supply of hydrogen at a lower cost is increasing. Thus far, several inherent limitations of each component of commercial water electrolysis systems have been discussed. In order to move closer to the ultimate aim of cost-effective production of clean H2 gas, we have also introduced mitigation strategies, mainly focusing on stability under intermittent renewable energy sources. For the design of cost-effective and durable components, some perspective points are provided below. OER catalyst Dissolution is the main issue in both PEMWE and alkaline-based electrolyzers. Consideration should be given to using passivation layers, dopants, and coating materials to protect OER catalysts from dissolution and irregular redeposition. Since most dissolved metal ions can penetrate the ion exchange membrane, which is unexpected in half-cell systems, the design of an interface between the catalyst layer and membrane should be suggested to prevent degradation caused by transported metal cations to the opposite electrode. Reduction of PGM can be achieved through the design of a new catalyst layer that differs from conventional nanoparticle-based catalyst layers. HER catalyst For durable operation, optimizations in terms of SMSI and wettability are crucial. Due to the innovative development of carbon-free support, the possibility of strong and durable SMSI opens up. Catalyst surface modification should be considered by balancing between aerophobicity to limit mass transport for extensive H2 production and wettability for reactant adsorption. Membrane Mechanical/chemical degradation is the main bottleneck of ion exchange membranes. For PEMs, membrane thinning including pinholes, occurring after durability testing, can be prevented by (1) reducing gas permeability and (2) using sacrificial materials to mitigate the Fenton’s reaction at the interface between the membrane and catalyst layer. AEMs face issues not only due to the Fenton’s reaction but also alkaline degradation caused by OH− and its radical species. This can be alleviated through the development of stable monomers resistant to both mechanisms. Separators for AWE encounter gas permeability issues, which hinder efficient operation at high current densities/pressures, rather than chemical stability. Optimizing the porous structure of the separator can help reduce gas permeability. PTL The formation of a native Ti oxide layer on the surface of Ti PTL leads to high contact resistance, contributing to low performance and durability in PEMWE. Surface modification with non-PGM-based materials should be adopted for cost-effective and durable operation. Stainless steel with a coating layer can be considered as the main material for PTL due to its low dissolution rate even in acidic media. Stainless steel-based PTL is also suitable for AEMWE and AWE conditions, but the flow field structure should be optimized to improve contact resistance. Bipolar plate Similar to the PTL case, surface coating on Ti and stainless steel with non-PGM-based materials is regarded as a mitigation solution for high conductivity and durability in PEMWE. For large-scale operation in the stage of commercialization preparation of electrolyzers, interpretation and optimization of the flow field in the bipolar plate should be conducted to ensure uniform temperature and reactant distribution as a function of current density, pressure, and temperature. Operating condition Compared to other components, the operating conditions necessary for stable operation when using intermittent renewable energy sources have been receiving increased attention. Beyond simple stability tests by applying constant current, AST tests including repetitive on/off cycles based on the intermittency of renewable energy sources should be adopted to confirm the stability of water electrolyzer systems. Since reduced performance can be recovered through certain dynamic protocols or circulation of acidic conditions, further regeneration protocols should be suggested to address reversible degradation. Additionally, applications of water electrolysis technology should be expanded by enhancing its unique advantages compared to other hydrogen production technologies. We hope that this review paper can serve as a guideline for designing new materials or operating conditions and contribute to achieving the ultimate technical target for cost-effective H2 production via water electrolysis systems. Kahyun Ham received her Ph.D. in School of Earth Sciences and Environmental Engineering from GIST, South Korea in 2021. She is currently working as postdoctoral researcher at Max–Planck–Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion in Germany. Her current interests are primarily focused on in situ spectroscopic analysis to investigate activation/degradation mechanism, particularly in (sea)water electrolysis conditions. She has published several scientific papers dealing with electrocatalysts and single-cell system in various international journals. Sooan Bae received her Ph.D. in School of Earth Sciences and Environmental Engineering from GIST, South Korea in 2024. She is currently working as postdoctoral researcher at GIST. Her research interests include electrocatalyst and MEA structure for pure-water-fed water electrolysis and Fe-based catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction in alkaline media. Jaeyoung Lee is the vice-director of the Ertl Center for Electrochemistry and Catalysis and a full professor at the School of Earth Sciences and Environmental Engineering, GIST, South Korea. He obtained his Ph.D. under Prof. Gerhard Ertl (2001) from the Fritz–Haber–Institut der Max–Planck–Gesellschaft and FU Berlin, Germany. He was a senior scientist at RIST/POSCO (2002–2004) and at the Fuel Cell Research Center, KIST (2004–2007). His-current research interests include Scale-up Science of water electrolysis, CO2RR, fuel cells and Li-S battery. He is currently the chair of ISE Scientific Meeting Committee, the president of Humboldt Club Korea and the representative of MPG Korea Alumni.

coredata.dc:description: Continuous efforts are underway to reduce carbon emissions worldwide in response to global climate change. Water electrolysis technology, in conjunction with renewable energy, is considered the most feasible hydrogen production technology based on the viable possibility of large-scale hydrogen production and the zero-carbon-emission nature of the process. However, for hydrogen produced via water electrolysis systems to be utilized in various fields in practice, the unit cost of hydrogen production must be reduced to $1/kgH2. To achieve this unit cost, technical targets for water electrolysis have been suggested regarding components in the system. In this paper, the types of water electrolysis systems and the limitations of water electrolysis system components are explained. We suggest guideline with recent trend for achieving this technical target and insights for the potential utilization of water electrolysis technology.
